text.p: Take a look at the video again. Which properties seem to be preserved by linear transformations from [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^2[/mathjaxinline] to [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^2[/mathjaxinline]?
For instance, does every transformation preserve the area of regions?
Do lines that start parallel always go in the same direction after transformation?
Do lines that start perpendicular remain perpendicular after transformation?

font.p: We see from the video that area is not preserved – the image can be much smaller or bigger after transformation than the original. Similarly, at time 2:12 in the video, we see an example of perpendicular lines not remaining perpendicular after a transformation.
However, parallel lines do always stay in the same direction, as seen in the video.
If you want to see a rigorous proof of this, click below.

div.p: Note that we can treat each point, [mathjaxinline](x,y)[/mathjaxinline], as a vector in standard position [mathjaxinline]\left[\begin{array}{c} x\\ y \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline]. Now, suppose [mathjaxinline]\ell _1[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]\ell _2[/mathjaxinline] are two parallel lines. If [mathjaxinline]\ell _1[/mathjaxinline] consists of points [mathjaxinline]p_1=\left[\begin{array}{c} x\\ mx+b_1 \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline] then [mathjaxinline]\ell _2[/mathjaxinline] consists of points [mathjaxinline]p_2=\left[\begin{array}{c} x\\ mx+b_2 \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline]. We will find the image of two points on each line and use these points to show the slope of the image lines, [mathjaxinline]T(\ell _ i)[/mathjaxinline], are the same. If [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is a linear transformation with standard matrix [mathjaxinline]A=\left[\begin{array}{cc} a & c\\ b& d \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline], then [mathjaxinline]T(\ell _1)[/mathjaxinline] contains the points [mathjaxinline]T(\left[\begin{array}{c} 0\\ b_1 \end{array} \right])=\left[\begin{array}{cc} a & c\\ b& d \end{array} \right]\left[\begin{array}{c} 0\\ b_1 \end{array} \right]=\left[\begin{array}{c} cb_1\\ db_1 \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline], and [mathjaxinline]T(\left[\begin{array}{c} 1\\ m+b_1 \end{array} \right])=\left[\begin{array}{cc} a & c\\ b& d \end{array} \right]\left[\begin{array}{c} 1\\ m+b_1 \end{array} \right]=\left[\begin{array}{c} a+cm+cb_1\\ b+dm+db_1 \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline]. Thus, [mathjaxinline]T(\ell _1)[/mathjaxinline] has slope [mathjaxinline]\frac{b+dm+db_1-db_1}{a+cm+cb_1-cb_1}=\frac{b+dm}{a+cm}[/mathjaxinline]. Similarly [mathjaxinline]T(\ell _2)[/mathjaxinline] contains the points [mathjaxinline]\left[\begin{array}{c} cb_2\\ db_2 \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]\left[\begin{array}{c} a+cm+cb_2\\ b+dm+db_2 \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline], so [mathjaxinline]T(\ell _2)[/mathjaxinline] has slope [mathjaxinline]\frac{b+dm+db_1-db_1}{a+cm+cb_1-cb_1}=\frac{b+dm}{a+cm}[/mathjaxinline]. Therefore, we see that the image of the two lines have the same slope.
